On Sat, Mar 15, 2003 at 06:22:44AM -0000, inthedarkplace wrote:
> --- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, "Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@s...>
> wrote:
> > From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@v...>
> > > As a general matter, would you want to PUT a
> > > MSWord6 document and GET a MSWord7 document?
> > 
> > Not if I couldn't read it with MSWord6.  Any of the items listed
> > above all fall under "can I use the GET version exactly like I use
> > the PUT version?"
> 
> I'm not sure why everybody thinks PUT is so limited and worse, why
> everybody thinks that GET must return _exactly_ what was previously
> PUT'ted. Again, like all the HTTP verbs, the server gets to
> **_interpret_** the body of the PUT request however it wants. It does
> not have to be a byte-for-byte copy (particularly since this reduces
> the server to just a plain old fileserver). Further, the body of a PUT
> is a _representation_ of a resource and representations are logical
> constructs which can be serialized to many different byte format and
> encoding schemes. 

Does this imply, then, that whenever a client issues a successful PUT
request, that the client should immediately perform a GET of that
request (or whatever uri was given in a Location header) if it wants to
do any further processing of that resource?

(I seem to remember some discussion of this a couple of months back, but
I don't think it was ever resolved)


> Also, I really don't think PUT should be used for resource creation.
> This is not only because PUT is idempotent and resource creation is
> usually a violent process full of side effects that it's not
> idempotent. Further, it's been my experience, that using PUT in this
> way just leads to all types of ambiguity and sutle bugs because
> neither the server or the client really know what's going on and it's
> always unclear whether a resource is being created or simply updated.  

That is why there is a difference between a 201 Created status code and
a 200 OK.

Personally, I'm all for using PUT to create resources, and creating
environments where that sort of thing _is_ idempotent. After all, that
is how it is supposed to be.


(2 cents later)
